news_title_translate_en: Staying in Portugal of people who come from areas affected by the coronavirus without restrictions
news_title_translate_cn: 来自受冠状病毒影响地区的人不受限制地留在葡萄牙
news_content_translate_en:
The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) reported this Wednesday that there are no restrictions on the stay in Portugal of children, young people and adults returning from an active coronavirus transmission area (Covid-19), but makes recommendations.
In a note published on its website, the DGS stresses that there are no restrictions on returning from an active community transmission area of the new coronavirus such as North Italy, China, South Korea, Singapore, Japan or Iran.
However, DGS advises that for 14 days these people should be attentive to the appearance of fever, cough or respiratory distress, and should measure body temperature twice a day and record values.
It also advises to check that any of the people with whom they live closely develop symptoms (fever, cough or respiratory distress) and if any of the above symptoms (in themselves or in their lives) should not immediately go to the health services.
The DGS also recommends people to call the number of Health Line 24 (808 24 24) and follow the indicated guidelines.
"Frequently wash hands with soap and water by rubbing them thoroughly for at least twenty seconds and strengthen washing hands before and after food preparation or meals after use of the bathroom and whenever hands are dirty" are other DGS recommendations.
People should also, according to DGS, use an alcohol-based solution a s an alternative for hand hygiene, use tissue (one-use-only) to blow, throw used tissues in a trash bin and wash hands afterwards and cough or sneeze into the arm with a bent elbow, rather than into their hands.Yeah.
The DGS also recommends avoiding touching the eyes, no s e and mouth with dirty hands or contaminated with respiratory secretions, remaining in closed and heavily frequented places within the 14 days of return and avoiding physical contact with other people.
The interim assessment of the Covid-19 coronavirus epidemic is of 2.800 dead and more than eight thousand infected people, according to data reported by 48 countries and territories.
Of the infected, over a 33 thousand have recovered.

The World Health Organisation declared the Covid-19 outbreak an international public health emergency and warned of a possible pandemic following a sudden increase in cases in Italy, South Korea and Iran in recent days.
In Portugal, the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) reported 25 suspected cases of infection, seven of which were still under study on Wednesday night.
The remaining 18 suspicious cases were not confirmed after negative tests.
In its first daily newsletter on the epidemic, released on Wednesday, the DGS indicated that, "according to current information, the risk to public health in Portugal is considered moderate to high.
The only known case of a Portuguese infected by the new virus is a crewman on a cruise ship who was admitted to a Japanese city hospital in Okazaki, situated about thirty miles southwest of Tokyo.

news_title_translate_en: Coronavirus triggers book sales "The Plague" and "Blindness Test" in Italy
news_title_translate_cn: 冠状病毒在意大利引发图书销售“瘟疫”和“失明测试”
news_content_translate_en:
The epidemic of Covid-19, caused by a new coronavirus, triggered the online sales of the novels "The Plague" by Albert Camus, and Joseph Saramago's "Blindness Test" in Italy, the most affected European country.
In times of fear of the new coronavirus detected in December in China, various cultural events and equipment have already been cancelled in order to avoid propagation, but on the other hand, the search for books, films, series or games that address the topic of pandemics has been increasing since the beginning of the year.
The latest indicators show an increase in book sales such as "The Plague" (1947), written by Franco-Algerian writer Albert Camus, Nobel Prize winner for Literature, whose 60th anniversary of death is noted this year, who is talking about a plague epidemic in the 1940s, which quickly takes over the whole city of Oron in Algeria.
Subject to quarantine, this city becomes an unbridled territory and its inhabitants are led into states of suffering, madness, but also compassion.
Last month in Italy-- the most affected European country, with three.089 cases of confirmed infection, over fifty thousand people were quarantined due to the Covid-19 outbreak.
In this country, Camus'book rose to the third place in portal ibs' top sales, when a month ago it was in 71st place, it reported the Italian newspaper "La Repubblica", in advance that the Amazon platform also recorded an increase in the book ranking in the category of classics, tripling sales.
In France, something similar happened, with 8.889 copies of "The Plague" being sold in the first two months of the year, when all last year the total sales were in the 22.400, according to the Edistat book sales statistics portalYeah.
Also Joseph Saramago's "Blindness Test" (1995), a writer who won the Nobel Prize for Literature three years later, became a literary phenomenon in Italy, having reached the top-10 of ibs and Amazon's 5th place, with an increase in 180% in sales.
The story tells of an epidemic of white blindness, which begins with a man inexplicably blinded when he is inside the car in the middle of traffic, and which spreads like a powder fuse, until collective blindness.
A situation similar to the search for these books is happening with films like Steven Soderbergh's "Contagion" (2011), in which a woman returning from a business trip to Hong Kong dies of a supposed flu, but the virus spreads and the deadly epidemic spreads, with doctors running out of time to try to identify the virus and fight it and stop the panic of the population.
"Contagion" is already among the ten most watched films on iTunes and among the fifteen most downloaded, according to Google Trends.
The Netflix documentary "Pandemia", which features heroes in a battle against flu and their work to prevent an outbreak around the world, which is not caused by the coronavirus, but shows that the world health system is not prepared to face a global health crisis, has also become a central issue on Twitter.
And as fear sells, various predictions are already on social media, one of which is reported in the novel "The Eyes of Darkness", by American science fiction writer Dean Koontz.
Published in 1981, with a reimpression in 1989, the book has a chapter on a disease called Wuhan-400, which is actually a biological weapon created in that Chinese city.
The page describing the consequences of the virus itself became viral, especially on Twitter: "They call it Wuhan-400 because it was created in one of the RDNA research laboratories outside the city of Wuhan, and it was strain n.400 of man-made micro-organisms created in this center. Wuhan is the perfect weapon. It only affects human beings. No other living thing can be a carrier."
Viral also became an image of the "Asterix in Italy" comic, published in 2017, where a driver named Coronavirus takes part in a chariot race, although it has nothing to do with any disease, being only a curiosity of name and country.
In these days of searching for catastrophic omens, also a warning from Bill Gates, made in February of 2017, was put into circulation. At the time, Microsoft's co-founder said that a pathogen that is airborne and rapidly moving "could kill more than half a million people in less than a year", although earlier in 2015 he had warned during a lecture that the world was not prepared "for a next epidemic".
The most catastrophic is the description written by Sylvia Browne in her 2008 book "End of Days: Predictions and Prophecies About the End of the World", which also spread through social networks, according to which a respiratory disease would erupt throughout the planet in the year 2020, and would not disappear until ten years had passed.
The Covid-19 outbreak, detected in December in China, which can cause respiratory infections such as pneumonia, caused about three.300 deaths and infected more than 95 thousand people in 79 countries, including eight in Portugal.
From infected people, more than fifty thousand have recovered.
In addition to three.012 killed in China, there are reports of fatalities in Iran, Italy, South Korea, Japan, France, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Australia, Thailand, the United States of America and the Philippines, San Marino, Iraq, Switzerland and Spain.
A Portuguese crewman of a cruise ship is hospitalized in Japan for confirmation of infection.
In Portugal, the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) confirmed eight cases of infection, of which six in Porto, one in Coimbra and one in LisbonYeah.
The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the Covid-19 outbreak an international public health emergency and increased the risk to "very high".
news_content_translate_cn:
由一种新型冠状病毒引起的Covid-19的流行，引发了阿尔伯特·加缪小说《瘟疫》的网上销售，以及约瑟夫·萨拉马戈在受影响最大的欧洲国家意大利的“失明测试”。
在人们担心中国12月发现新的冠状病毒的时候，为了避免传播，各种文化活动和设备已经被取消，但另一方面，从年初开始，人们对涉及流行病主题的书籍、电影、系列或游戏的搜索一直在增加。
最新的指标显示，《瘟疫》（1947）等书的销量有所增加，该书由诺贝尔文学奖得主、法裔阿尔及利亚作家阿尔伯特·加缪（Albert Camus）撰写，加缪今年是他的逝世60周年纪念日，他正在谈论1940年代的瘟疫，瘟疫迅速席卷了阿尔及利亚的整个奥伦市。
由于受到隔离，这个城市变成了一个肆无忌惮的领土，它的居民被带进了痛苦、疯狂和同情的状态。
上个月，在意大利这个受感染最严重的欧洲国家，有3089例确诊感染病例，超过5万人因Covid-19病毒爆发而被隔离。
在这个国家，加缪的书在门户网站ibs的销量排行榜上上升到第三位，一个月前，加缪的书排在第71位，它提前报道了意大利报纸《共和国报》，亚马逊平台的经典类图书排名也有所上升，销量翻了两番。
在法国，类似的情况也发生了，根据Edistat图书销售统计门户网站的数据，《瘟疫》的销量在今年前两个月达到了889册，去年全年的总销量为22400册是 啊。
同样，三年后获得诺贝尔文学奖的作家约瑟夫·萨拉马戈（Joseph Saramago）的《失明测试》（1995）也成为意大利的一种文学现象，在ibs排行榜上排名前十，亚马逊排名第五，销量增长了180%。
这个故事讲述了一种白盲的流行，一开始是一个男人在车里堵车时莫名其妙地失明，然后像火药引信一样扩散，直到集体失明。
像史蒂文·索德伯格（Steven Soderbergh）的《传染病》（2011）这样的电影也出现了类似于寻找这些书籍的情况，在这部电影中，一名从香港出差回来的妇女死于一种假定的流感，但病毒传播，致命的流行病蔓延，医生们已经没有时间去识别病毒并与之抗争，从而阻止民众的恐慌。
根据谷歌趋势（Google Trends）的数据，《传染病》已经跻身iTunes十部最受关注的电影和下载量最高的十五部电影之列。
Netflix的纪录片《Pandemia》也成为Twitter上的一个中心议题，该片讲述了抗击流感的英雄们以及他们为防止全球范围内的流感爆发所做的工作，而这并不是由冠状病毒引起的，但显示出世界卫生系统还没有准备好面对全球卫生危机。
随着恐惧的蔓延，各种各样的预测已经出现在社交媒体上，其中一个在美国科幻作家迪恩·孔茨的小说《黑暗之眼》中有报道。
1981年出版，1989年再版，书中有一章是关于一种叫做武汉-400的疾病的，它实际上是一种在中国城市制造的生物武器。
描述这种病毒本身的后果的网页变成了病毒，特别是在Twitter上：“他们称之为武汉-400，因为它是在武汉市外的一个RDNA研究实验室中创建的，是n株在这个中心创造了400个人工微生物。武汉是完美的武器。它只影响人类。任何其他生物都不能成为载体。”
病毒也成为2017年出版的“意大利阿斯特里克斯”漫画的一个形象，一个名叫冠状病毒的司机参加了一场战车比赛，尽管这与任何疾病无关，只是对名字和国家的好奇。
在这些寻找灾难性征兆的日子里，比尔盖茨于2017年2月发出的警告也开始流传。当时，微软的联合创始人说，一种通过空气传播并迅速传播的病原体“可能在不到一年的时间内杀死50多万人”，尽管在2015年早些时候，他在一次演讲中警告说，世界并没有为“下一次流行病”做好准备。
最具灾难性的是西尔维娅·布朗在其2008年出版的《末日：世界末日的预言和预言》一书中所作的描述，这本书也通过社交网络传播开来，根据这本书，一种呼吸道疾病将在2020年在地球上爆发，直到十年过去才会消失。
去年12月在中国发现的可导致肺炎等呼吸道感染的Covid-19疫情，在79个国家造成约3300人死亡，9.5万多人感染，其中包括葡萄牙的8人。
从感染者那里，已经有五万多人康复了。
除了3.012人在中国丧生外，还有伊朗、意大利、韩国、日本、法国、香港、台湾、澳大利亚、泰国、美利坚合众国和菲律宾、圣马力诺、伊拉克、瑞士和西班牙的死亡报告。
一艘游轮上的葡萄牙船员在日本住院确认感染。
在葡萄牙，卫生总局确认了8例感染病例，其中6例在波尔图，1例在科英布拉，1例在里斯本是 啊。
